            By 
Hanna Trudo

11/12/15 08:11 PM EST
Donald Trump lashed out at Ben Carson on Thursday, likening his "pathological" temperament to that of a child molester’s. 
In an appearance on CNN’s "Erin Burnett OutFront," the billionaire businessman said that there is no cure for his 2016 presidential opponent’s “pathological temper.” 
Story Continued Below
Throughout the interview, Trump took jabs at Carson’s memoir.
“It's in the book that he's got a pathological temper," he said. 
"That's a big problem because you don't cure that ... as an example: child molesting. You don't cure these people. You don't cure a child molester. There's no cure for it. Pathological, there's no cure for that."
Carson has been upfront about bursts of violent behavior in the past. In "Gifted Hands," Carson’s autobiography published in the late 1990s, he wrote that his behavior is due to a “pathological temper,” which made headlines recently in relation to an anecdote from Carson’s youth about an attempt to stab a friend. 



            By 
Eliza Collins

Trump has taken issue this week with one specific passage in which Carson wrote, "I had what I only can label a pathological temper — a disease — and this sickness controlled me, making me totally irrational." 
On Thursday, Trump reiterated that he was not adding anything new to the conversation separate from what Carson already penned. 
"I'm not bringing up anything that's not in his book," he said, and added, “I'm not saying anything other than pathological is a very serious disease. And he said he's pathological.”

title: Trump calls Carson's temper 'pathological,' cites 'child molester' as example of condition
